its a general misunderstanding that quants must have many advanced stats/ maths foundation.

quant daily work includes fixing bugs / optimise performance of current platforms (e.g backtest, real trade GUI), optimising existing alpha (e.g. computation speed, efficiency, predictive power etc) and build pipline for new alpha. Most tasks require extensive coding, from scratch or on legacy code.

how to train programming skills if I target such kinds of jobs?

replies.msg:
build your portfolio to demonstrate your coding skills and analytical skills. it could be a web crawler, dashboard on some interesting data, visualization of a deep learning model, applying ML on unstructured data, kaggle competition ... etc.
1. start with a very simple template, and then gradually upgrade the project. e.g. if you work on web crawler of house price, try scraping one district's house price manually first. And then think about scaling it up to all districts, scraping it in a more efficient way (using selenium / direct API request), storing data as a db, scraping in real time, generating dashboard from the data you have scraped. There are many extension you can work on ... etc. It makes your project solid and talkable in an interview.
2. by the time you work on those projects, try to write modular code and make it readable. publish your work on github so that it's visible to your recruiters.
